elements.content: The novel M[(OPPh2)2N]2·nTHF (M = Sr (2), Ba (3)) complexes were prepared and characterized. Upon exposure to atmospheric oxygen, 2 and 3 were transformed to the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C4H8O3 (5), respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 contain coordinated carboxylic acids obtained from the oxidative degradation of DME and THF, respectively, which were used as solvents for crystallization.
elements.clean_text: The novel M[(OPPh2)2N]2⋅nTHF (M = Sr (2), Ba (3)) complexes were prepared and characterized. Upon exposure to atmospheric oxygen, 2 and 3 were transformed to the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C4H8O3 (5), respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 contain coordinated carboxylic acids obtained from the oxidative degradation of DME and THF, respectively, which were used as solvents for crystallization.

elements.content: The novel M[(OPPh2)2N]2·nTHF (M = Sr (2), Ba (3)) complexes were prepared and characterized. Upon exposure to atmospheric oxygen, 2 and 3 were transformed to the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C4H8O3 (5), respectively. Upon exposure to atmospheric oxygen, 2 and 3 were transformed to the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C4H8O3 (5), respectively. elements.content: Transition-metal oxides in high oxidation states are known to be stoichiometric oxidation agents for ethers capable of oxidizing them to the corresponding carboxylic acids, esters, or lactones. Thus, attempts have been made to develop such types of oxidizing agents with catalytic behavior. Transition-metal complexes such as CoCl2, Co(acac)3, RuCl2[(CH3)2SO]4, and [Pd(PtBu2H)(μ-P t Bu2)]2 have proven to be active in the aerobic oxidation of cyclic and acyclic ethers to lactones, where this process is catalytic in the case of Ru and Pd. Moreover, Rh and Ir complexes catalyze the oxidation of THF to γ-butyrolactone in the presence of small amounts of water. Additionally, the bimetallic complexes Ind(CO)3Mo−Ru(CO)2Cp and Fe2(μ-O2CArt°l)2(Me2TACN)2(MeCN)2(OTf)2 have been used to promote the catalytic oxidation of THF.
elements.clean_text: Transition-metal oxides in high oxidation states are known to be stoichiometric oxidation agents for ethers capable of oxidizing them to the corresponding carboxylic acids, esters, or lactones. Thus, attempts have been made to develop such types of oxidizing agents with catalytic behavior. Transition-metal complexes such as CoCl2, Co(acac)3, RuCl2[(CH3)2SO]4, and [Pd(PtBu2H)(μ-P t  Bu2)]2  have proven to be active in the aerobic oxidation of cyclic and acyclic ethers to lactones, where this process is catalytic in the case of Ru and Pd. Moreover, Rh and Ir complexes catalyze the oxidation of THF to γ-butyrolactone in the presence of small amounts of water. Additionally, the bimetallic complexes Ind(CO)3Mo-Ru(CO)2Cp and Fe2(μ-O2CArt°l)2(Me2TACN)2(MeCN)2(OTf)2 have been used to promote the catalytic oxidation of THF.

elements.content: Recently, we have reported on a calcium tetraphenylimidodiphosphinate complex containing coordinated α-hydroperoxytetrahydrofuran molecules formed by in situ oxidation of the solvating THF. Because hydroperoxides are known intermediates in the oxidative ring opening of THF, we decided to study the oxidation abilities of tetraphenylimidodiphosphinate complexes based on the heavier alkaline-earth metals, strontium and barium, toward cyclic and acyclic ethers. Herein, we describe the synthesis and characterization of Sr[(OPPh2)2N]2·2.8THF (2) and Ba[(OPPh2)2N]2·3THF (3), along with the crystal structures of the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4·2C4H8O3 (5). Compounds 4 and 5 contain carboxylic acids obtained by the aerobic oxidative degradation of DME and THF, respectively. To our knowledge, this is the first case where main-group metals proved to be active in an oxidative degradation of ethers.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have reported on a calcium tetraphenylimidodiphosphinate complex containing coordinated α-hydroperoxytetrahydrofuran molecules formed by in situ oxidation of the solvating THF. Because hydroperoxides are known intermediates in the oxidative ring opening of THF, we decided to study the oxidation abilities of tetraphenylimidodiphosphinate complexes based on the heavier alkaline-earth metals, strontium and barium, toward cyclic and acyclic ethers. Herein, we describe the synthesis and characterization of Sr[(OPPh2)2N]2⋅2.8THF (2) and Ba[(OPPh2)2N]2⋅3THF (3), along with the crystal structures of the dinuclear species Sr2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C3H6O3 (4) and Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4⋅2C4H8O3 (5). Compounds 4 and 5 contain carboxylic acids obtained by the aerobic oxidative degradation of DME and THF, respectively. To our knowledge, this is the first case where main-group metals proved to be active in an oxidative degradation of ethers.

elements.content: 2 was obtained in high yield (94%) by bubbling dry NH3 through a suspension of tetraphenylimidodiphosphinic acid (1) and activated Sr in THF, whereas the reaction of BaCl2·2H2O with K[(OPPh2)2N] in THF led to the formation of Ba[(OPPh2)2N]2·3THF (3) in 85% yield. Compounds 2 and 3 are white powders sparingly soluble in CH2Cl2 and CHCl3 but insoluble in most organic solvents. Their 1H NMR spectra display the characteristic signals corresponding to the phenyl groups at δ 7.2−7.8 ppm along with the characteristic signals for THF (δ 3.88 and 1.78 ppm for 2 and δ 3.70 and 1.67 ppm for 3). The 31P NMR spectra show singlets at δ 17.6 and 17.7 ppm for 2 and 3, respectively. The IR spectra of 2 and 3 exhibit strong absorption bands at 1260 and 1262 cm-1, respectively, corresponding to the νas(P2N) stretching. The MS-FAB+ of 2 and 3 reveals peaks at m/z 921 and 971, respectively, corresponding to the [M[(OPPh2)2N]2]+ fragments.
elements.clean_text: 2 was obtained in high yield (94%) by bubbling dry NH3 through a suspension of tetraphenylimidodiphosphinic acid (1) and activated Sr in THF, whereas the reaction of BaCl2⋅2H2O with K[(OPPh2)2N] in THF led to the formation of Ba[(OPPh2)2N]2⋅3THF (3) in 85% yield. Compounds 2 and 3 are white powders sparingly soluble in CH2Cl2 and CHCl3 but insoluble in most organic solvents. Their 1H NMR spectra display the characteristic signals corresponding to the phenyl groups at δ 7.2-7.8 ppm along with the characteristic signals for THF (δ 3.88 and 1.78 ppm for 2 and δ 3.70 and 1.67 ppm for 3). The 31P NMR spectra show singlets at δ 17.6 and 17.7 ppm for 2 and 3, respectively. The IR spectra of 2 and 3 exhibit strong absorption bands at 1260 and 1262 cm-1, respectively, corresponding to the νas(P2N) stretching. The MS-FAB+ of 2 and 3 reveals peaks at m/z 921 and 971, respectively, corresponding to the [M[(OPPh2)2N]2]+ fragments.

elements.content: Attempts to grow X-ray-quality crystals of 2 and 3 from their DME and THF solutions, respectively, resulted in the oxidation of the coordinated solvent molecules. Thus, crystals of a dinuclear complex 4 were obtained from a DME solution of 2 upon storage at ambient temperature for several weeks. Similarly, 5 was isolated from a THF solution of 3 in a quantitative yield (Scheme ). The coordination of methoxyacetic and γ-hydroxybutyric acids to the metal centers in 4 and 5, respectively, clearly indicates an in situ oxidation of the solvents used for their crystallization. To gain further insight into this process, we followed the reaction using 1H NMR spectroscopy. Periodic measurement of the 1H NMR spectra of THF solutions of 2 and 3 under aerobic conditions revealed the presence of α-hydroperoxytetrahydrofuran molecules after 1 week. Thus, we confirmed the presence of α-hydroperoxide as an intermediate in the oxidative degradation of these solvents. It is noteworthy to mention that no evidence of an oxidation process was observed in the absence of air. Moreover, studies using BaCl2 and SrCl2 in THF under conditions similar to those mentioned above showed no significant formation of α-hydroperoxytetrahydrofuran. Therefore, the oxidation behavior of 2 and 3 can be considered as a property of these complexes as a whole and not as an intrinsic property of the metal centers involved.

To gain further insight into this process, we followed the reaction using 1H NMR spectroscopy. elements.content: Compounds 4 and 5 exhibit spectroscopic patterns similar to those of their parent compounds 2 and 3. Additionally, a peak at m/z 1941 assigned to the Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4 fragment of 5 revealed the dimeric nature of this compound, which was further confirmed by X-ray structural analysis. The crystal structures of 4 and 5 are illustrated in Figures and , respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 crystallize in a triclinic space group P1̄ with half of the molecule in the asymmetric unit.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 4 and 5 exhibit spectroscopic patterns similar to those of their parent compounds 2 and 3. Additionally, a peak at m/z 1941 assigned to the Ba2[(OPPh2)2N]4 fragment of 5 revealed the dimeric nature of this compound, which was further confirmed by X-ray structural analysis. The crystal structures of 4 and 5 are illustrated in Figures  and , respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 crystallize in a triclinic space group P1̄ with half of the molecule in the asymmetric unit.

elements.content: The centrosymmetric dinuclear complex 4 contains heptacoordinated strontium atoms in distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The two P−N−P ligands are not equivalent; the first is chelating with both oxygen atoms attached to the same Sr atom (O1 and O2), whereas the second is bridging between the strontium atoms (O3 and O4). The coordination sphere at each Sr atom is completed by the etheric oxygen atom (O7) and μ 3 -O of the carbonyl group (O5) belonging to two methoxyacetic acid molecules. The bridging coordination of the carbonyl group results in a planar Sr2O2 core with a Sr···Sr distance of 4.370(2) Å. Although there are no similar compounds for comparison, this Sr···Sr distance is within that observed for multinuclear strontium complexes containing Sr2O2 units (3.425−4.564 Å).
elements.clean_text: The centrosymmetric dinuclear complex 4 contains heptacoordinated strontium atoms in distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The two P-N-P ligands are not equivalent; the first is chelating with both oxygen atoms attached to the same Sr atom (O1 and O2), whereas the second is bridging between the strontium atoms (O3 and O4). The coordination sphere at each Sr atom is completed by the etheric oxygen atom (O7) and μ 3 -O of the carbonyl group (O5) belonging to two methoxyacetic acid molecules. The bridging coordination of the carbonyl group results in a planar Sr2O2 core with a Sr⋅⋅⋅Sr distance of 4.370(2) Å.  Although there are no similar compounds for comparison, this Sr⋅⋅⋅Sr distance is within that observed for multinuclear strontium complexes containing Sr2O2 units (3.425-4.564 Å).

elements.content: The five oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5, O5A, and O7) of the bipyramidal base are nearly in the same plane (sum of the angles 360.1°), whereas the axial angle O3−Sr1-O4A is 167.1°. The Sr1−O4A (2.396(2) Å) and Sr1−O3 (2.411(2) Å) bond lengths corresponding to the bridging ligands are slightly shorter than those for the nonbridging Sr1−O bonds (average 2.509(2) Å). The P−N−P angles for the bridging ligands (139.1(1)°) are more obtuse than those for the nonbridging ligands (127.6(1)°). Similar to 4, compound 5 is a dimeric centrosymmetric species with two heptacoordinated barium atoms displaying highly distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal environments (Figure ). Two μ 3 -O atoms (O1 and O1A) from two equivalent molecules of the ligand bridge the barium atoms and form a planar Ba2O2 core with a Ba···Ba distance of 4.254(7) Å. The second oxygen atoms of these ligand molecules (O2 and O2A) coordinate each to one barium atom. Each barium atom is further coordinated to another molecule of the ligand (O3 and O4) and the oxygen atoms of the hydroxy (O7B) and carbonyl (O5) groups from two molecules of γ-hydroxybutyric acid. The equatorial sites around Ba1 are occupied by O1, O4, O5, O7B, and O3. The first four oxygen atoms and Ba1 are located within the same plane with a mean deviation of 0.049 Å, while O3 lies 0.969 Å out of the plane. The axial positions are occupied by O1A and O2, giving an axial angle of 155.6(1)°. In both compounds, the COOH and OH protons are involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonding. On the basis of the coordination environment of the barium, compound 5 is best described as a polymeric chain of inorganic cores linked by molecules of γ-hydroxybutyric acid and surrounded by phenyl groups.

The Sr1-O4A (2.396(2) Å) and Sr1-O3 (2.411(2) Å) bond lengths corresponding to the bridging ligands are slightly shorter than those for the nonbridging Sr1-O bonds (average 2.509(2) Å). The P-N-P angles for the bridging ligands (139.1(1)°) are more obtuse than those for the nonbridging ligands (127.6(1)°). Similar to 4, compound 5 is a dimeric centrosymmetric species with two heptacoordinated barium atoms displaying highly distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal environments (Figure ). Two μ 3 -O atoms (O1 and O1A) from two equivalent molecules of the ligand bridge the barium atoms and form a planar Ba2O2 core with a Ba⋅⋅⋅Ba distance of 4.254(7) Å. The second oxygen atoms of these ligand molecules (O2 and O2A) coordinate each to one barium atom. Each barium atom is further coordinated to another molecule of the ligand (O3 and O4) and the oxygen atoms of the hydroxy (O7B) and carbonyl (O5) groups from two molecules of γ-hydroxybutyric acid. The equatorial sites around Ba1 are occupied by O1, O4, O5, O7B, and O3. The first four oxygen atoms and Ba1 are located within the same plane with a mean deviation of 0.049 Å, while O3 lies 0.969 Å out of the plane. The axial positions are occupied by O1A and O2, giving an axial angle of 155.6(1)°. In both compounds, the COOH and OH protons are involved in intramolecular hydrogen bonding. On the basis of the coordination environment of the barium, compound 5 is best described as a polymeric chain of inorganic cores linked by molecules of γ-hydroxybutyric acid and surrounded by phenyl groups.

elements.content: In summary, the hitherto unknown imidodiphosphinate complexes of group 2 metals represent a new class of entities capable of achieving oxidative degradation of cyclic and acyclic ethers. This noteworthy feature opens a new perspective for the application of group 2 metals. Further research is currently underway to determine the nature of this oxidative process.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the hitherto unknown imidodiphosphinate complexes of group 2 metals represent a new class of entities capable of achieving oxidative degradation of cyclic and acyclic ethers. This noteworthy feature opens a new perspective for the application of group 2 metals. Further research is currently underway to determine the nature of this oxidative process.

metadata.title:
Oxidative Degradation of Ethers Promoted by Strontium and Barium
Tetraphenylimidodiphosphinates
